subject: Sunday at Octocon
event:
Having a great, if exhausting, time at Octocon in Dublin.  The Irish fen are wonderfully hospitable, and the BWBers are great company, as always.

I am still feeling borderline sick and my time sense is knackered, however.  I hit the wall at seemingly random moments and have to stagger off to nap, absp;utely canNOT keep my eyes open... but then I sleep for an hour or two, get a second wind, and wake up ready to roar late into the night.  Last night I had to collpase after supper, but O staggered down again in time to pick the raffle winners, then partied till three in the morning, swilling down coke after coke and arguing about sex in the books.  Somehow I found myself between half a dozen women who want some explicit male/male scenes in the books and a couple of dissenters who don't... from there we wandered into Myrish swamps and were never seen again...

It was a strange night.  Today I'm paying for it.

comments.article:
Linda joins those half-dozen ladies. I'm not sure toasty Loras is exactly what they want, but maybe a flashback?

As to the rest of your post.... When lost in a Myrish swamp, the number one rule of survival is look for the fat pink mast, it'll always guide you home. (As learned on Ray Mears' Extreme Survival!)

(Linda suggests it'd be like a beacon in the night, but if it's glowing, you've got bigger problems, says I...)

Sounds like a great time!

[For those who are curious about the Q&A session, lady narcissa wrote up a transcript here. As to the chapter George read, we've a report from a previous reading, but skip on down to the last page or two for some differences in th version as read at Octocon.

These reports are in no way a substitution for hearing it live and in full, but good stuff if you're keen on getting spoiled.]

Oh, definitely some m/m. Pwetty please.

You know what you did with that comment, right? Because there will be a score or so comments asking for some guy love. :)

You're dealing with, what, 8 hours of west-to-east jetlag? West coast USA to Ireland? That's pretty horrible; I usually allow 24 hours for lying up followed by 2-5 days for full recovery afterwards.

(The only way to make it worse is to add a northern/southern hemisphere switch; California to South Africa, say, or UK to south-eastern Australia. Either of which are just brutal.)

Be glad Octocon is back in Dublin and not out in Maynooth.
Sounds like its fun in a taxing sort of way.  Hope the rest of trip goes well. :)

Somehow I found myself between half a dozen women who want some explicit male/male scenes in the books

Yes please! *thumbs up!*
That'll be the Incredible Hulks Sean had you drinking ...
<3 your avatar!  :)

comments.upictitle: Arthur Venture: Arthur Writer Venture Drawing Philosophy
comments.article:
Please George, don't work yourself so hard. Get some rest. Please take better care of yourself.

I'm not totally averse to the idea of a m/m scene, it's your book, you write it the way you want to.
comments.subject: Concerned fan.

comments.article:
"From there we wandered into Myrish swamps and were never seen again.."

Sounds like someone got some, Mr. Martin.
comments.subject: Myrish swamps

comments.article: Speaking of male/male sex, something I heartily endorse, it was vaguely implied that Renly and Loras may have had a thing going.  Was this just a rumor in Westeros or was it true?
I didn't catch that whole subtext when I read through, but once someone told me it just made sense.
I also am a female that would love to see a male/male scene in the books. Too bad Loras is out of commission, ha ha ha~
I mean, did you HAVE to indicate that Loras is out of commission? Not everyone here have read the books! Have some respect please!
comments.subject: SPOILERS warning would have been nice!!!

comments.article:
Ugh. No thanks. Keep your book about the story. There's a bit too much graphic sex in ASoIaF as it is in my opinion (I'm no prude, they just don't really *add* anything).

Plus... I don't really need that image in my head. Dudes are gross. I sometimes even wonder why all women aren't into other women, considering how completely manly we men are. It's like being attracted to a boulder. Or pavement.

I heard a really cool quote by George (on one of his podcasts, I think) in response to complaints about gratuitous sex in the books. Something along the lines of: "Nobody ever complains about the gratuitous feasting".

Can we have bigger banquets in the next book, please? :)

I'm male, but I'd like a m/m scene too. True, I'm bisexual, so that might be a good reason for it, but I also think it's needed to balance things out.
You've quite lovingly included and described several sex scenes, both m/f and f/f, and in the later case I feel they were somewhat out of character(everyone's a critic, eh? what is the world coming to?).
I'm no sexuality expert, but it just felt weird to see two characters who have never shown any attraction(and still don't) to females perform sexual acts with another female, one for being lonely and horny(or whatever Danny's reasons were) and the other for...craving power and wanting to feel dominant?

From personal experience I can tell that before I started having feelings towards men as well around my 18th year, the thought of a man touching me would've positively revolted me, and I believe heterosexual women think the same about being touched by another woman.
It just felt so out of place and more of a fan-service thing, begging your pardon.

So now we want some tasteful m/m action with characters already established as gay/bi, please(unless my cute Loras bites the dust...you cruel, cruel author!).
It was an interesting night, and a good con (or so I thought, can't really judge though, it having been my first). Hope you got one or two interesting ideas from it.

How to put this delicately...

Oh please God no for the sake of my sanity don't?

I don't want to come off as homophobic, but I could be spared the details. Yeah, yeah, double standard and all that, but even as a comfortably straight young male I thought the scenes in "Feast" were a bit over the top.

But in seriousness, do women really have an interest in m/m, as men do vice versa, or is this just an interest in equality?
comments.subject: O-o

comments.article: I'm a man, I'm hetero, and I definitely got an interest in m/m scenes, so there's absolutely no need to genderize this.
comments.subject: Re: O-o

comments.article:
First of all, thank you sir for replying to my message on the previous thread. I am glad to hear that John Howe has already had some involvement with your work. I hope to see more in the future!

I also got my copy of Ted Nasmith's "A Song Of Ice And Fire" calendar, and the work is truly wonderful. Personally, I feel that it does justice to your own great work. The whole calendar is captivating, but some of my personal favourites are "Winterfel", "Storms's End" and "The Wall". "The Wall" and "Storm's End" give me goosebumps everytime I look at them!

I wanted to ask you, I know that it is not up to you, and I am aware that oftentimes you depend on HBO for any news like the rest of us, but since you are more intimately involved with "A Game Of Thrones", I was wondering, are there any news on who will work on the soundtrack for the show?

I must say that many fans, me included, would love to see Bear McCreary involved with the project. His soundtrack for "Battlestar Galactica" was fantastic to say the least! I have been listening to the work he did on "Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles" (starring the beautiful Lena Headey...I feel some kind of Six Degrees of Separation coming on...ah poor Kevin Bacon!) and I love it. His most recent work is the soundtrack for another great show "Caprica", which is the prequel to "Battlestar Galactica". He would most definitely be an asset to HBO...

Harry Gregson Williams who scored Ridley Scott's masterpiece "Kingdom Of Heaven", would, in my mind, also be a worthy candidate, as would a true HBO stalwart, Jeff Beal, who scored the fascinating "Carnivale" and the truly awesomely epic "ROME". Or what about the team of Rob Lane and Joseph Vitarelli who created the truly moving music for "John Adams", another high point of HBO programming!

I know that you have no control over any of this, but any insight or tidbits would be most welcome, as I personally think that music is soo important, especially for such work of high quality as "A Song Of Ice And Fire"! One only has to look at what Howard Shore (any chance of getting him?), did for Peter Jackson's LOTR trilogy. I couldn't imagine the movies withouth Shore's music!

Look forward to this one...
comments.subject: Eire

comments.article: Please, please, no m/m sex scenes.  As posted previously, it won't add to the story.  I don't read your books for the sex scenes, and I don't think you cater yourself as a romance author.
comments.subject: m/m sex scene

comments.article:
I beg to differ, sir, since GRRM is and always was quite a romantic author... read some of his other works if u doubt it even though ASOIAF has a lot of romance woven into it, heck, it started and drives the damn plot, basically... And please tell me, do you presume to lecture your other favorite authors on what they should and should not include in their books?? If so, and your blatant rudeness here is not incidental, then I advise you start writing your own series (potentially involving priests and nuns with their private parts sewn shut...

and George, I love you! :D
comments.subject: Re: m/m sex scene

comments.article: From what I've heard, Pillars of the Earth(the book series) was ruined by too many sex scenes. My friends speculate is was the sexual frustration of the author.  I made that same assumption about Michael Bay when I saw transformers 2.  ASOIAF has had enough sex scenes to portray some of the characters in different lights.  I mean I am cool knowing what happened, but I have no interest in trashy novels.  The only sex scene left that I won't mind is the one between Jon Snow and Dany.  Grasping for straws to add some m/m scene for the fans to an otherwise beautiful series seems gaudy.
comments.subject: sex scenes

comments.article: My thinking on Jon and Dany was the same as yours, but I've changed my mind on that.  I think you need to look more into the past than the future.  But I'm just guessing.
comments.subject: Re: sex scenes

comments.article:
Ok... I'll be a naysayer since there seems to be a supportive pull in the m/m corner so far. (From reading above, I'm now trying to remember where a f/f scene took place, it escapes my memory)

Anywho, explicit m/m is an extreme reading turnoff for straight males. Extreme spelled with a capital X, flashy lights at a Hollywood opening and a bloated advertising campaign. You know... Xtreme turnoff.

Not looking to burst bubbles here, but I'd very much like to avoid any m/m scenarios in my much beloved reading. I'll give a short story on how this can effect a reading experience adversely. I was reading Myrren's Gift by Fiona McIntosh. Very strong start, good ideas, well written, violent, assassinations etc etc (book had a complete lack of sex thus far). Enjoying the read. Story continues, turns out one of the main characters is, very surprisingly gay, and suddenly forests are farting out unicorns and a fuzzy assortment of cutesy animals. (not kidding about the forest)

Writing this is difficult without sounding like a homophobe. Being lead by the author to like and respect a manly character, who then does what appears to be, and feels like, a 180 turn in direction for what one would expect of his traits, and to have a seemingly 'straight' story take an about face... it felt dishonest and it put me off the book, series, and author, entirely.

Were GRRM to do it, I'd just have to gloss over that section and continue on, because he's too damn good a writer not to forgive it. For a lesser author, they're in the bucket.

Many ladies like the m/m... I'll never understand why, but I do understand that much. If one of Gregor's men were to rape a village boy, that would be in character, and to a degree expected. It would be like reading a torture scene, but it would fit in the books. Were Jon Snow to take a turn for the other team with Stannis... just throw me to the Others.

"Anywho, explicit m/m is an extreme reading turnoff for straight males. Extreme spelled with a capital X, flashy lights at a Hollywood opening and a bloated advertising campaign. You know... Xtreme turnoff."

I don't think you get to speak for all straight males. And male male sex scenes are more of a turn off to you than incest, another adult topic handled dealt with in ASOIAF? Really?

"Writing this is difficult without sounding like a homophobe. Being lead by the author to like and respect a manly character, who then does what appears to be, and feels like, a 180 turn in direction for what one would expect of his traits, and to have a seemingly 'straight' story take an about face... it felt dishonest and it put me off the book, series, and author, entirely."

The reason it's difficult is because it is in fact strikingly homophobic. Is your point that a manly man can't be gay? Do you actually know any gay men?

"If one of Gregor's men were to rape a village boy, that would be in character, and to a degree expected. It would be like reading a torture scene, but it would fit in the books. Were Jon Snow to take a turn for the other team with Stannis."

So the only acceptable gay sex is rape of children?

Seriously. You need to take a minute an examine your prejudices.
comments.subject: Let me understand what you're saying
Re: No, you didn't really get it.
Re: No, you didn't really get it.
Re: No, you didn't really get it.
Re: No, you didn't really get it.
Re: No, you didn't really get it.
Re: No, you didn't really get it.
Re: No, you didn't really get it.
Re: Let me understand what you're saying

Re: Let me understand what you're saying
Re: Let me understand what you're saying

comments.article: When I first read the books, I thought Loras and his sister were lovers in a way to mirror Jamie and Cersei based on the fact he was spending so much secret time with her and her friends. I didn't think about there being a gay side of it until meantioned on the website.

Seriously?  Hot "boy on boy" action? 

I'm not in favor of censorship, but if a sex scene doesn't further the story somehow, why is it there?  Titillation?  Do you really expect people to masturbate to ASOIAF?  

That's what the internet's for!  

Tell those damned Irish to buy laptops...or lap dances.  Either way, keep the porn (and, yes, I DO know it when I see it) out of Westeros.  Just because you write fantasy for adults doesn't mean you have to write for "mature audiences."  I hate that porn gets to be called "adult" and "mature," as if fumbling yourself like a monkey was the path to wisdom.  I wish it was...I'd be a freakin' monk by now.

Sex happens, I think the vast majority of your readers are cool with that.  But, please, keep it relevant.

What was the point of the myrrish swamp scene? IMO it was titillation and very, very little more. All it really showed was just how nasty Cersei was at this point, willing to finger some woman she has no attraction to only for political gain. Ugh. Also by the zillionth time Tyrion f***ed Shae I was ready to move on. I think we got the idea that he's obsessed by the 2nd time. The rest of the scenes really were just titillation.

The point of a Loras/Renly scene should be obvious to anyone who reads the book deeply. Unlike most of the sex in aGoT, it would actually be love based (only love based sex other than this was probably Ned/Cat).

Wandered into Myrish swamps??

Now there's a euphemism if I've ever heard one. ;)

why so many women are fascinated with male homosexuality?
Whats so interesting about it?
comments.subject: So does anyone know

comments.article: Why do so many men find f/f sex fascinating?
comments.subject: Re: So does anyone know

comments.article:
For purely selfish reasons I would prefer no m/m scenes.

Logically I know there is nothing wrong with them, and I was actually a bit surprised that we were never invited to watch one of Renly and Loras' "armor donning" scenes.

Am I predjudiced against the idea of m/m interaction? No. Are my personal tastes predjudiced? Anyone who would answer that one in a negative is a lier or does not understand the question. Of course my tastes are predjudiced to what I find tasteful.

So, to add a little counter to the dominating view point being in favor of m/m scenes, I would have to ask, respectfully, that such narrative is left out of the books. It would make a difficult read a bit more difficult.

On the other hand... reading things that make one uncomfortable is a good way of exercising the big gray muscle between your ears. Your books, Mr Martin, are wonderfully uncomfortable at times. It only seems appropriate, and it would truly fit, to have such scenes included in those gritty pages.

Not that the opinions of a few fans should influence you. The books should spring from your muse, not our prattling.

Anyway, enough of my slightly schizophrenic rambling... if it takes a hot and heavy Renly/Loras flashback to get this book on the shelves so be it! (ill just skim over those parts...)
comments.subject: a little schiz...

comments.article: Now that's a much classier way saying what I think avernus_wpg was trying to say.  I agree that everyone has personal preferences of what they would like to read or not read in books.  If reading graphic male-male sex scenes (or any sex scenes for that matter) makes you uncomfortable, then there's nothing wrong with saying so. But seeing as George has no problem graphically describing the murder of small children, I don't think he's really going to be swayed by arguments that gay sex makes some people feel icky.
comments.subject: Re: a little schiz...

comments.article:
If it makes sense do it. If not, don't. I think your readers have more or less come to expect you not to pull any punches, one way or another.

People get offended for all kinds of reasons. I do think it's funny that people are okay reading about incest and rape and children having sex and whatnot - so long as it's heterosexual sex.

Two consenting male adults having sex and suddenly the book is ruuuuined. Hahaha.

george,

we're all bigger fans of your series then even you, the author, can probably fathom. we are taunted week in and week out by clever, yet vague, insinuations as to the status of DwD, and we stomach them with the patience that only a fantasy aficionado can possess.

perhaps in the spirit of generosity you could provide your (loyal and undying) fans with a concrete update on the book. we all love wildcards, and your other side projects, but we hang onto news of DwD with the desperation of...okay, im overdrawn at the imagery bank, but suffice it to say that we want an update. not on the hbo series (which i'm more excited about than any show EVER), or on any of your side projects (all of which i support and purchase), but on a song of ice and fire, which has won our fanship and our loyalty as readers.

please, just give us something to grasp on to!

from a devout and passionate reader.
There have been many updates about DwD on this very blog over the last year.  George hasn't been moving them to the main page, but there have been a lot of them here.
comments.subject: Updates

comments.article:
With all due respect, discussion over scenes included in the next book sounds premature to me (we have no book yet, and art can`t be rushed). But maybe you can rewrite a few chapters, if a majority of your readers would like to include them. Enjoy Ireland !

As to the upcoming talks with your publishers, good king Joffrey will have their heads on spikes if they rush you to hard. Or maybe I just send them to the Wall.
